features.category: Careful Use of Motion and Animation
details: Purpose: Guide attention, communicate system responses, clarify actions without overwhelming.
Subtlety: Animations should be subtle and purposeful.
Duration: 200–300ms for responsiveness.
Easing: Incorporate easing and acceleration to mimic natural movement (start slow, speed up, slow down).
Accessibility: Always provide an option to reduce or disable motion for users with motion sensitivity or vestibular disorders.
Purposeful Animation: Every animation should serve a purpose (highlight state change, draw attention, provide feedback).
Avoid Decorative: Do not use overly decorative animations that might confuse or distract.
Testing: Test animations with real users.

Identify Key Onboarding Moments: Map user journey, pinpoint friction points (e.g., completing forms, discovering features, drop-off areas). Example: Attention Insight's progress bars boosted activation by 47%.

Define Triggers, Rules, and Feedback: Tailor each component (trigger, rule, feedback, loops/modes) to specific onboarding moments. Examples: HubSpot's chatbot typing indicator, Simplenote's password error feedback, Mailchimp's celebratory GIFs.

Prototype and Test: Use tools like UXPin to build interactive prototypes with real code. Leverage pre-built component libraries (MUI, Tailwind UI, Ant Design). Use AI Component Creator for new patterns. Collaborate with team using real-time feedback. Conduct early and frequent user testing.

Iterate Based on Feedback: Gather quantitative (completion rates, task durations, drop-off) and qualitative (user interviews, usability tests) data. Consider accessibility (options to reduce motion, assistive technologies). Make small, incremental changes. Document successes and failures.
Overloading Users: Too many interactions, flashy effects, heavy animations (opt for lightweight CSS animations). Should enhance primary task, not distract.
Inconsistent Design Patterns: Unpredictable behavior, varying timings erode trust. Use style guides, design systems, and pattern libraries for consistency (e.g., Gmail's swipe-to-delete).
Neglecting Feedback and Testing: Assumptions can lead to confusing interactions. Regular user testing is crucial. Accessibility testing is vital (keyboard navigation, high-contrast color schemes).
Making onboarding smoother, more enjoyable, and easier to navigate.

Makes product approachable, builds trust, inspires exploration.

Clear visual cues and text alternatives for visual feedback.
All interactive elements fully keyboard-navigable.
High-contrast color schemes for visual challenges.
Following accessibility guidelines.
